facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 633 and 634 of 1964

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 633 and 634 of 1964. Appeals from the judgement and order dated July 23 and 24, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 61 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgement and order dated July 23 and 24, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 61 of 1961

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgement and order dated July 23 and 24, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 61 of 1961. V. Viswanatha Sastri, S.N. Vakil, T.A. Ramachandran, B. Dadachanji, O.C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellant  in both the appeals .

facts.text: The appellant, the Poona Electric Supply Co., Ltd., carried on the business of distribution of electricity in the city of Poona under a licence issued by the Government

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Poona Electric Supply Co., Ltd., hereinafter called the Company, carried on the business of distribution of electricity in the city of Poona under a licence issued by the Government. Under the relevant provisions of the Electricity  Supply  Act, 1948,  Act 54 of 1948 , hereinafter called the Act, the Companys clear profit in any year should number, as far as possible, exceed the amount of reasonable return as defined under the Act.

facts.text: During the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 the Company claimed deduction of two amounts of Rs. 42,148/- and Rs. 77,138/- for the said two years from its taxable income as they were credited to Consumers Benefit Reserve Account

anchor.surface_text: The excess, if any, after making some deductions, the Company has to distribute to its companysumers in the form of rebate. During the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 the Company claimed deduction of two amounts of Rs. 42,148/- and Rs. 77,138/- for the said two years from its taxable income as they were credited to Consumers Benefit Reserve Account.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim

anchor.surface_text: . The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim and on appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer. On a further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal accepted the companytention of the appellant and allowed the deductions.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer

anchor.surface_text: and on appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer. On a further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal accepted the companytention of the appellant and allowed the deductions. At the instance of the Revenue, the Tribunal submitted the following question of law to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay for its opinion

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal accepted the contention of the appellant and allowed the deductions

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal accepted the companytention of the appellant and allowed the deductions. At the instance of the Revenue, the Tribunal submitted the following question of law to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay for its opinion Whether the two sums of Rs. 42,1481- in the assessment year 1953-54 and Rs. 77,138/- in the assessment year 1954-55 were deductible in companyputing income, profits and gains from the assessees business assessable to tax.

facts.text: A Division Bench of the Bombay High Court answered the question in the negative and against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the said High Court answered the question in the negative and against the appellant. The present appeals have been filed by the Company after obtaining the requisite certificate from the High Court.

facts.text: The present appeals have been filed by the Company after obtaining the requisite certificate from the High Court

anchor.surface_text: The present appeals have been filed by the Company after obtaining the requisite certificate from the High Court. The argument of Mr. A.V. Viswanatha Sastri, learned companynsel for the appellant, may be summarised thus  1  There is a distinction between companymercial profit of a companypany and clear profit under the Act---one is arrived at on companymercial principles and the other is regulated by the statute the real profit of a companypany under s. 10 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act can be determined only after excluding the amount statutorily transferred to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account, for that amount represents a rebate to the customers of the excess amount companylected from them.

facts.text: The Company follows the mercantile system of accounting

facts.text: Under the relevant provisions of the Electricity Supply Act, 1948, the Companys clear profit in any year should number, as far as possible, exceed the amount of reasonable return as defined under the Act

anchor.surface_text: Under the relevant provisions of the Electricity  Supply  Act, 1948,  Act 54 of 1948 , hereinafter called the Act, the Companys clear profit in any year should number, as far as possible, exceed the amount of reasonable return as defined under the Act. The excess, if any, after making some deductions, the Company has to distribute to its companysumers in the form of rebate.

facts.text: Paragraph I of the Sixth Schedule imposes a duty on every such licensee to so adjust his rates for the sale of electricity by periodical revision that his clear profit in any year shall number, as far as possible, exceed the amount of reasonable return

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph I of the Sixth Schedule imposes a duty on every such licensee to so adjust his rates for the sale of electricity by periodical revision that his clear profit in any year shall number, as far as possible, exceed the amount of reasonable return. The expressions clear profit and reasonable return are defined. Under Para. II thereof if the clear profit of a licence in any year of account is in excess of the amount of reasonable return, one-third of such excess, number exceeding 7 1/2 of the amount of reasonable return, shall be at the disposal of the undertaking one half of the said excess shall either be distributed in the form of a proportional rebate on the amounts companylected from the sale of electricity and meter rentals or carried forward in the accounts of the licensee for distribution to the companysumers in future in such manner as the State Government may direct.

facts.text: if the clear profit of a licensee in any year of account is in excess of the amount of reasonable return, one-third of such excess, number exceeding 7 1/2 of the amount of reasonable return, shall be at the disposal of the undertaking one half of the said excess shall either be distributed in the form of a proportional rebate

facts.text: The liability to return the amounts was incurred by the assessee during the relevant accounting years

anchor.surface_text: The liability to return the amounts was incurred by the assessee during the relevant accounting years. This Court held in Calcutta Co. Ltd., v. Commissioner Income-tax, West Bengal 1  that where an assessee maintained his accounts on mercantile basis, the accrued liability and the estimated expenditure which it would incur in discharging the same companyld be deducted from the income of the accounting year in which the said liability accrued.

facts.text: No person can supply electric energy in any area unless he has obtained a licence from the State Government under s. 3 1  of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910

anchor.surface_text: To appreciate the rival companytentions and to arrive at a satisfactory solution it will be necessary to numberice the relevant provisions of the Act and of the Income-tax Act. The gist of the relevant provisions may be stated thus No person can supply electric energy in any area unless he has obtained a licence from the State Government under s. 3 1  of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910  9 of 1910 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: managing agency companymission is made, agreed to or given on grounds of companymercial expediency, simply because it takes place some time after the

arguments.court_reasoning: Plausible but fallacious; equates clear profit (statutory) with commercial profits; Sixth Schedule for rate control, not tax.

arguments.claim: Profits and gains under s.10(1) of the Income-tax Act are business profits computed on business principles, not statutory profits; real profit cannot include amounts returned by way of rebate under statutory compulsion.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 10  1  of the Income-tax Act, tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head profits and gains of business in respect of profits and gains of any business carried on by him. The said profits and gains are not profits regulated by any statute, but profits in a business computed on business principles. They are business profits and not statutory profits. They are real profits and not notional profits.

arguments.claim: There is a clear-cut distinction between deductions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits.

anchor.surface_text: There is a clear-cut distinction between deductions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits. In a given case whether the outgoings fall in one or the other of the heads is a question of fact to be found on the relevant circumstances, having regard to business principles.

arguments.claim: The amounts credited to Consumers Benefit Reserve Account are part of excess reserved to be returned to consumers and do not form part of assessee's real profits; deductible under s.10(1) to arrive at taxable income.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of the Act, during the accounting years the assessee credited the said amounts to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account. They were part of the excess amount paid to it and reserved to be returned to the consumers. They did not form part of the asessees real profits.

arguments.claim: Where assessee maintains mercantile accounts, accrued liability and estimated expenditure deductible in year liability accrues.

anchor.surface_text: The liability to return the amounts was incurred by the assessee during the relevant accounting years. This Court held in Calcutta Co. Ltd., v. Commissioner Income-tax, West Bengal 1  that where an assessee maintained his accounts on mercantile basis, the accrued liability and the estimated expenditure which it would incur in discharging the same could be deducted from the income of the accounting year in which the said liability accrued.

arguments.claim: Rebate under Electricity Act is deduction for ascertaining real profits, analogous to cases like Union Cold Storage, British Sugar Manufacturers where payments reference to profits deductible if for ascertainment not distribution.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Court of Appeal in British Sugar Manufacturers, Ltd. v. Harris  Inspector of Taxes 1  is rather instructive. There, a company carrying on a manufacturing business agreed with two other companies to pay them a stated percentage of its net profits in consideration of their giving to the company the full benefit of their technical and financial knowledge and experience,

holdings.text: The said amounts credited to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account have to be deducted from the assessee's total income to arrive at the taxable income from business under s. 10(1) of the Income-tax Act as they did not form part of the assessee's real profits.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of the Act, during the accounting years the assessee credited the said amounts to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account. They were part of the excess amount paid to it and reserved to be returned to the consumers. They did not form part of the assessee's real profits. So, to arrive at the taxable income of the assessee from the business under s. 10(1) of the Act, the said amounts have to be deducted from its total income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Real profits under s.10(1) exclude statutory rebates returned to consumers; computed on commercial principles, not statutory clear profit under Electricity Act.

holdings.text: Profits and gains under s.10(1) of the Income-tax Act are business profits computed on commercial principles, not statutory profits regulated by any statute like clear profit under the Electricity Supply Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 10(1) of the Income-tax Act, tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head 'Profits and gains of business' in respect of the profits and gains of any business carried on by him. The said profits and gains are not profits regulated by any statute, but profits in a business computed on business principles. They are business profits and not statutory profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes statutory rate regulation purpose of Sixth Schedule from tax on real commercial income; follows real income doctrine.

holdings.text: There is a clear-cut distinction between deductions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits; the rebate here is a deduction for ascertaining real profits.

anchor.surface_text: The said decisions lead to the following results: Income-tax is a tax on the real income, i.e., the profits arrived at on commercial principles subject to the provisions of the Income-tax Act. The real profits can be ascertained only by making the permissible deductions. There is a clear-cut distinction between deductions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies business principles and precedents like Union Cold Storage, British Sugar Manufacturers distinguishing ascertainment vs appropriation of profits.

holdings.text: Where an assessee follows mercantile system of accounting, the amounts reserved for rebate are deductible in computing income for the accounting year in which the statutory liability to return them accrues.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the amounts so reserved for future payment were deductible in computing the income, profits or gains from the assessee’s business for the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55. It is not disputed that the assessee adopts the mercantile system of accounting. The liability to return the amounts was incurred by the assessee during the relevant accounting years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability accrued in relevant years; follows Calcutta Co. Ltd. precedent on deducting accrued liabilities under mercantile basis.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether the said amounts are allowable as deductions under s.10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In this view it is not necessary to express our opinion on the question whether the said amounts would be allowable deductions under s. 10(2)(xv) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deductible under s.10(1) itself; no need to consider alternative provision.

holdings.text: The question referred to the High Court whether the two sums of Rs.42,148/- and Rs.77,138/- were deductible in computing the assessee's business income is answered in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, this legal position was not contested on behalf of the Revenue. In the result we answer the question referred to the High Court in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on real income principle, distinction between commercial and statutory profits, and mercantile accounting rules.

precedents.citation: Pondicherry Railway Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: In Pondicherry Railway Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 . under an agreement with the French Colonial Government the railway companypany had to pay to the said Government half of its net profits calculated as provided thereunder.

precedents.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: A payment out of profits and conditional on profits being earned cannot accurately be described as a payment made to earn profits
precedents.cited_holding: Payments to French Government of half net profits not deductible under s.10(2)(ix)

anchor.surface_text: Lord Chancellor Halsbury in Gresham Life Assurance .Society v. Styles 2 , proceeded to observe The word profits I think is to be understood in its natural and proper sense in a sense which numbercommercial man would misunderstand.

precedents.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v Styles
precedents.cited_proposition: Profits to be understood in natural commercial sense; destination of profits immaterial for tax

precedents.citation: The Indian Radio and Cable Communications Cornpony, Ltd., The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay Presidency AdenC

anchor.surface_text: The statement in the aforesaid observations that a payment companyditional on profits being earned cannot be a payment made to earn profits has been modified and explained by the Privy Council in The Indian Radio and Cable Communications Cornpony, Ltd., The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay Presidency AdenC .

precedents.case_name: Indian Radio and Cable Communications Company Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Payment conditional on profits being earned not always non-deductible; exception for director's commission

anchor.surface_text: To that extent the principle laid down by Lord Macmillan in the case of Pondicherry Railway Co. 2 has been modified.

precedents.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle that conditional payment out of profits not deductible

precedents.citation: The Union Cold Storage Co. Ltd., v. Adamson  H. M. Inspector of Taxes  3

anchor.surface_text: Lord Macmillan himself in a later decision in The Union Cold Storage Co. Ltd., v. Adamson  H. M. Inspector of Taxes  3  explained his observations in the Pondicherry Railway Co.s case  2 .

precedents.case_name: Union Cold Storage Co Ltd v Adamson
precedents.cited_proposition: Rent abatements repaid are deductible in ascertaining profits, not distribution

anchor.surface_text: explained his observations in the Pondicherry Railway Co.s case  2 . There, the appellant-company leased lands and premises abroad under a deed reserving a particular rent per annum.

precedents.citation: British Sugar Manufacturers, Ltd. v. Harris  Inspector of Taxes 1

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Court of Appeal in British Sugar Manufacturers, Ltd. v. Harris  Inspector of Taxes 1  is rather instructive. There, a companypany carrying on a manufacturing business agreed with two other companypanies to pay them a stated percentage of its net profits

precedents.case_name: British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd v Harris
precedents.cited_proposition: Payments measured by reference to profits can be deductible if for purpose of earning profits; different senses of 'profits'

precedents.citation: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee again in Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta 1  emphasized the companycept of real income in the companytext of payment of income-tax.

precedents.cited_proposition: Tax only on real income of taxpayer, not charges upon income

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of the Act, during the accounting years the assessee credited the said amounts to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account. They were part of the excess amount paid to it and reserved to be returned to the consumers. They did not form part of the assessee's real profits. So, to arrive at the taxable income of the assessee from the business under s. 10(1) of the Act, the said amounts have to be deducted from its total income.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 10(1) of the Income-tax Act, tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head 'Profits and gains of business' in respect of the profits and gains of any business carried on by him. The said profits and gains are not profits regulated by any statute, but profits in a business computed on business principles. They are business profits and not statutory profits.

anchor.surface_text: The said decisions lead to the following results: Income-tax is a tax on the real income, i.e., the profits arrived at on commercial principles subject to the provisions of the Income-tax Act. The real profits can be ascertained only by making the permissible deductions. There is a clear-cut distinction between deductions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 on rebate as deduction for ascertaining real profits addresses issue i2 on deductibility of amount returned for ascertaining taxable income.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the amounts so reserved for future payment were deductible in computing the income, profits or gains from the assessee’s business for the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55. It is not disputed that the assessee adopts the mercantile system of accounting. The liability to return the amounts was incurred by the assessee during the relevant accounting years.
In the result we answer the question referred to the High Court in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee. The order of the High Court is set aside.
